Okay so I want to tell you about soccer
balls, actually I want to tell you about
spheres. So here's the fact that I want
to tell you: if you have the surface of a
sphere like this, you could think the
surface of the earth or something, we can
divide it up into pieces. So the way I'm
going to do that is using what are
called vertices, edges, and faces. So
vertices are like dots; so maybe I'll put
a dot there and a dot there. Edges are
going to connect vertices. So here's one
edge, and then maybe I'll draw another
edge around the back. And then faces are
pieces that are bounded by the edges; so
in this picture, the way I've divided it
up, one face is the upper hemisphere of
the sphere and the other face is the
lower hemisphere of the sphere. Okay so
why did I divide it up like that? Well I
want to use this really cool thing
called the Euler characteristic. So if
you've watched the video about Brussels
sprouts we talked about the Euler
characteristic before. So this is going
to be the Euler characteristic for a
sphere: it says that the number of
vertices minus the number of edges plus
the number of faces is always equal to
2. So this is a well-known mathematical
fact, the Euler characteristic is
something- we could do this for other
shapes too, not just spheres, so like we
could take the Euler characteristic of
the surface of a doughnut if you wanted
to. So usually we write this letter chi
for the Euler characteristic. The Euler
characteristic of a doughnut is zero. And
you can take the Euler characteristic of
other surfaces too, like have you ever
been to one of those - do they have these
in Australia? - the waterparks with the

double inner tube rides?

Yeah I love those things. Okay, so if
we consider one of those double inner
tubes, that thing has Euler
characteristic negative 2. So the Euler
characteristic can be different for
different shapes that we have; for the
sphere though the Euler characteristic
is always 2. And what I mean when I say
always is even if you did the vertices,
edges, and faces differently - like why did
I pick two vertices and two edges and
two faces? - we'd still get the number 2.
Say for instance like I added some

So let's say that P is going to be the
number of pentagons on a soccer ball
and H is the number of hexagons. The way
we're going to do it is using the Euler
characteristic which means we need to
count vertices, edges, and faces.
Let's count faces because that one's the

this is that we're dividing it up using
these edges that are naturally on the
soccer ball, and the vertices are like
these points where the edges come
together, and the faces are the

there? Well if there are P pentagons
and H hexagons the number of faces is

to do this we need to remember a
pentagon has five sides, right?
So for each pentagon we get five edges. A
hexagon has six sides
so for each hexagon we get six edges.
That total's not quite right though
because if you look at one of these
edges on the soccer ball it's actually
on two different faces. So when we did

twice, so we need to divide the total by
2 to get the actual number of edges.
Because like this edge is on a pentagon

but every edge is on two different faces
so we over counted. So now let's try to
count the vertices: the vertices are
these points at the corners.
So each pentagon has five of those, each
